poem:
Title: "Under A Stark Northern Sky"

In the tight, stone-caged town of my youth,
Where spring crept slow as a reluctant poet's truth,
I felt Lancashire's cage, grey-washed in its pall,
Apthly named and shaped to an armpit's thrall.
Yet blossomed, in this unlikely spot,
A queer spectacle - yielding to naught.

Against Orwell's vision, dressed in bold counterclaim,
Drag's shimmering defiance, a phoenix aflame.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Drag is under attack across the world: RuPaul’s Drag Race shows why we need it more than ever | Max Wallis In the northern market town where I grew up, winter took a long time to pass into spring, and even then something about the sky made me feel hemmed in. I used to call it the armpit of Lancashire. It wasn’t quite George Orwell’s The Road to Wigan Pier, but when I looked in". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
